results.title: The all singing all dancing show; Power and prejudice
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Best of British”.
The All singing all dancing show features a time when Britain produced screen musicals that were innovative, exciting and visually stunning. This episode uncovers jewels with scenes from films like “The Red shoes” and “London town”, and a host of stars including Jessie Matthews, Kay Kendall and Moira Shearer. “Power and Prejudice” focuses on films that reflect social attitudes, struggles and problems of ordinary people. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: Leave 'em laughing; The Eccentrics
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Best of British”.
Leave ‘em laughing features scenes from some of the finest British comedies and some of its greatest comedians; Sid Field, Jerry Desmond, Norman Wisdom, Will Hay and the Carry On Gang. “Eccentrics” is filled with some of the most endearing characters to appear on film; Dame Edith Evans, Sir Michael Redgrave, Cecil Parker, Alistair Sim, Peter Sellers and the gentle, amusing and complusive to watch, Margaret Rutherford. This volume captures the essence of British comedy at its best. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: The War game. Heroes
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Best of British”.
The War Game examines the British approach to war with scenes from some of the most famous movies ever made, such as” Waterloo Bridge”, “Henry V” and the “Life and times of Colonel Blimp”. “Heroes” makes the comparison between heroes of American cinema and their British counterparts. A tribute is made to the “stiff upper lip” hero played by the likes of Leslie Howard, Jack Hawkins, Stewart Granger, Alec Guinness and David Niven in a variety of roles from spy to school boy. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: The Beehive
results.credit_line:
Zanny Begg

Digital video, stereo sound, variable duration

Artbank + ACMI Commission, ACMI Collection
results.material_description: Single channel digital video and software, colour and audio
results.brief_description: The Beehive explores the unsolved murder of Sydney anti-development campaigner Juanita Nielsen. The inaugural Artbank + ACMI Commission, the video installation examines themes of gentrification, corruption, sex-work, feminism and non-conformist lifestyles.

constellations_other.name: Neo-noir
constellations_other.description: Blade Runner's retro-futurist setting lends it a timeless quality, while also connecting it to the past and the future.

constellations_other.name: Women and crime
constellations_other.description: The allure and fascination of dangerous women and women in danger.

results.description:
Zanny Begg’s The Beehive is the inaugural Artbank + ACMI Commission supporting ambitious and experimental screen-based work at the nexus of film and art.

The Beehive is a non-linear experimental documentary exploring the unsolved murder of Sydney anti-development campaigner and glamourous style icon Juanita Nielsen in Kings Cross in 1975. Juanita’s body has never been found and her murderers have never been charged.

The Beehive consists of scripted fictions, documentary interviews and choreographed scenes with multiple actors playing the role of Juanita. The film is ever-changing, as a different combination of footage is randomly selected for each screening with 1,344 possible variations. The Beehive therefore continually morphs and evolves to reveal different interpretations of this violent historical act and its social context. Operating like a forensic investigation, the film presents a variety of puzzle pieces, asking new questions and potentially pointing to an answer.

The title is a reference to Juanita Nielsen’s famous hairdo but is also a metaphor for human cities. In classical times the beehive was seen as a hierarchical and densely industrious hub; in pre-Christian symbolism the beehive was a dark cooperative womb guided by a powerful queen. This clash between utilitarian and feminist interpretations of our cities provides a poetic tension that flows through the film.

Who killed Juanita Nielsen?
description_for_label: The Beehive explores the unsolved murder of Sydney anti-development campaigner Juanita Nielsen. The inaugural Artbank + ACMI Commission, the video installation examines themes of gentrification, corruption, sex-work, feminism and non-conformist lifestyles.
results.credit_line_for_label:
Zanny Begg

Digital video, stereo sound, variable duration

Artbank + ACMI Commission, ACMI Collection

results.title: The Bedspread
results.creator_credit: Natalie Green, Elizabeth O'Neill and Berry St Film Productions
results.brief_description: Concerns two poverty-stricken women, Mrs Clancy and Mrs Parsons, living in Melbourne during the depression. Mrs Clancy owns a good bedspread, her pride and joy. Mrs Parsons asks to borrow the bedspread in preparation for a visit by a specialist to her sick daughter. This small incident becomes the focal point of the day. Cast includes Janet Robertson, Moira Claux and Kim Deacon. Based on a short story by Iris Simmons.

results.title: The Best of Dad's army. Vol. 2 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Harold Snoad, David Croft and BBC
results.brief_description: Popular comic English television program “Dad’s army”, which ran for nine years, is about numerous men that comprise the local division of the Home Guard in the seaside town of Walmington-on-Sea during World War 2. The men are an eccentric lot who range in age from the very young to the decidedly doddery. In each episode the group muddle their way through a different situation in their won idiosyncratic way. Episodes on this DVD include: “No spring for Frazer” (1969, 30 mins) Frazer looses the spring from Captain Mainwaring’s machine gun, which may have ended up in Mr Blewitt’s coffin. “Mum’s army” (1970, 31 mins) Captain Mainwaring recruits women-folk to help fight the Nazis. “Menace from the deep” (1969, 30 mins) The Home Guard is manning the machine gun post, Pike’s lost the boat and the food, and the platoon is nearly blown sky high. “When did you last see your money?” (1972, 30 mins) Jones causes mayhem at the bank when he tries to pay half a pound of sausages into his account. “The Honourable man” (1973, 31 mins) When Sergeant Wilson loses a relative he finds himself on the outer fringes of the aristocracy, much to the chagrin of Mainwaring.

results.title: The Best of Dad's army
results.brief_description: Popular comic English television program “Dad’s army”, which ran for nine years, is about numerous men that comprise the local division of the Home Guard in the seaside town of Walmington-on-Sea during World War 2. The men are an eccentric lot who range in age from the very young to the decidedly doddery. In each episode the group muddle their way through a different situation in their own idiosyncratic way. Episodes on this DVD include: “The Deadly attachment” (1973, 30 mins) The platoon are ordered to guard a captive German U-Boat crew. “Keep young and beautiful” (1972, 30 mins) Concern over the condition of some of the elder members of the unit precipitates a frenzy of invigorating activities. “Never too old” (1972, 36 mins) Jones falls in love and becomes increasingly absent-minded much to the dismay of his cohorts. “Asleep in the deep” (1972, 30 mins) A bomb falls on the local plumbing station; Privates Walker and Godfrey require rescuing but typically the entire platoon become trapped. “Sons of the sea” (1973, 30 mins) Captain Mainwaring plans to patrol the rivers in order to keep the Nazis at bay.

results.title: The Best of Bowie
results.brief_description: This disc contains 47 film clips of British singer and musician David Bowie. Bowie, who has experienced an illustrious career, has always been at the forefront of trends and new waves in music and fashion. These clips spanning a thirty-year career, reflect Bowie’s chameleon personality and the diversity of his art. The music videos are directed by a variety of people including Mick Rock, D.A. Pennebaker, Stanley Dorfman, David Mallet, Jim Yukich, Julien Temple, Steve Barron, Mark Romanek, Gus Van Sant, Jean Baptiste-Mondino, Roger Michell, Floria Sigismondi and Walter Stern. Other songs have live clips, which serve as a fascinating reflection of the changing face of music over the decades. Songs include: Oh! You Pretty Things; Queen Bitch; Five Years; Starman; John, I’m Only dancing; The Jean Genie; Space Oddity; Drive-In Saturday; Life On Mars?; Ziggy Stardust; Rebel Rebel; Young Americans; Be My Wife; Heroes; Boys Keep Swinging; D.J.; Look Back In Anger; Ashes To Ashes; Fashion; Wild Is The Wind; Let’s Dance; China Girl; Modern Love; Cat People (Putting Out Fire); Blue Jean; Loving The Alien; Dancing In The Street; Absolute Beginners; Underground; As The World Falls Down; Day-In Day-Out; Time Will Crawl; Never Let Me Down; Fame 90; Jump They Say; Black Tie White Noise; Miracle Goodnight; Buddha Of Suburbia; The Hearts Filthy Lesson; Strangers When We Meet; Hallo Spaceboy; Little Wonder; Dead Man Walking; Seven Years In Tibet; I’m Afraid Of Americans; Thursday’s Child and Survive.

results.title: The Renaissance: 1400-1550
results.creator_credit: Joyce Fox, Matt Newman, Mary Watanabe, Janet Schloat, Educational Audio Visual and Clearvue
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History through art”.
In the 15th Century Western civilisation developed the printing press and the resulting accessibility of knowledge led to renewed interest in the ancient cultures of Greece and Rome. In the wealthy cities of Florence and Venice the superstitions and anti-humanism of the Middle Ages began to be replaced by philosophies in which human potential and creativity was deemed infinite. Through the art of this period this video explores the historic conditions which gave rise to the Renaissance. In this period philosophies of art, culture, science, politics and theology were to be developed which still have a central role in contemporary Western consciousness and social practice. The video features the works of da Vinci, Michelangelo, Donatello, Botticelli as well as the sculpture, architecture and craft of the Renaissance.

Episode of Series “History through art”.
In the 15th Century Western civilisation developed the printing press and the resulting accessibility of knowledge led to renewed interest in the ancient cultures of Greece and Rome. In the wealthy cities of Florence and Venice the superstitions and anti-humanism of the Middle Ages began to be replaced by philosophies in which human potential and creativity was deemed infinite. Through the art of this period this video explores the historic conditions which gave rise to the Renaissance. In this period philosophies of art, culture, science, politics and theology were to be developed which still have a central role in contemporary Western consciousness and social practice. The video features the works of da Vinci, Michelangelo, Donatello, Botticelli as well as the sculpture, architecture and craft of the Renaissance.

results.title: The Best of Big Brother
results.creator_credit: Simon Francis, Andrew Farrell, Lara Hopkins, Endemol Entertainment and Southern Star Entertainment
results.brief_description: Big Brother is the history-making reality television program that was franchised around the world and quickly became a phenomenon when first broadcast in Australia. The program celebrates the excesses of the reality television genre and delivers the ultimate promise to would-be-voyeurs by filming it’s ‘contestants’ constantly for the duration of the show (with the help of 23 cameras). The program, run as a winner takes-all competition, placed twelve strangers in a house (six girls and six boys) to live with each other for a period of three months (85 days). A set of rules were put in place, along with a number of set tasks (or challenges) that had to be completed (or performed) by the house-mates. Each week a house-mate would be voted off by the public from the show, whilst the competition grew and the public interest intensified to a dramatic climax that revealed the final winner. Relive the fun, drama, screams, precocious parading and much un-scripted antics of the original twelve that dared show us all how they could cope under 24 hour surveillance! Hosted by Greta Kileen.
